title: Dallas tornado: More than 100,000 customers remain in the dark
text:
Tens of thousands of residents woke up without power in Texas Monday after a tornado touched down in Dallas, leaving a path of destruction that damaged structures and downed power lines.

Continue Reading Below

As of Monday morning, more than 100,000 electric customers in the state remain in the dark, according to power company Oncor.

Over 160,000 state outages have been reported, according to an outage map provided by Poweroutage.US.

Oncor said early Monday that there’s no estimated time of restoration, although “crews are working as quickly and as safely as possible to restore power to those impacted by the storm" while urging residents to "stay safe and stay away from downed power lines.” The utility says the damage to power lines took place east of Interstate 35, an area that includes Dallas.

The National Weather Service confirmed a tornado touched down in Dallas late Sunday night near Love Field Airport. However, Texas isn't in the clear yet. A tornado watch has been issued for parts of Arkansas, Louisiana, Oklahoma and Texas until 10 a.m. Monday, according to the weather service.

Viewers shared images of the tornado with FOX 4 News.

CLICK HERE TO GET THE FOX BUSINESS APP

The storm also forced numerous schools to close. Six Dallas Independent School District campuses have canceled class on Monday, as has The Episcopal School of Dallas.

Dallas Fire-Rescue says there have been no reports of fatalities or serious injuries in the aftermath, but three people were hospitalized for evaluation of non-life-threatening injuries.

Spokesman Jason Evans says search teams conducted primary assessments on accessible structures for six hours overnight, but their efforts were “hampered by limited access and lack of proper lighting.” A second set of teams will resume search efforts in daylight.

CLICK TO READ MORE ON FOX BUSINESS

This story is a developing story. Check back for updates.

The Associated Press contributed to this report.
description: As of Monday morning, more than 100,000 electric customers in the state remain in the dark, according to power company Oncor.
